questions.question: What's the basic difference between full frame and crop sensor cameras?
options: Full frame uses film; crop uses digital
Full frame has a larger sensor; crop sensor is smaller (e.g., APS-C)
Full frame changes a lens's focal length
questions.reviewHint: Sensor size differs → affects field of view, noise, and depth of field.

questions.question: A 50 mm lens on a 1.5× crop camera gives a field of view similar to which lens on full frame?
You frame the same head-and-shoulders portrait at f/2.8 on both cameras (adjusting distance/focal length to match framing). Which gives shallower depth of field?
options: Depends only on the lens brand
questions.reviewHint: For same framing & f-number, full frame tends to have shallower DOF.

questions.question: In low light at higher ISOs, which typically shows less noise (cleaner images), all else equal?
questions.reviewHint: Larger sensors usually have better high-ISO performance.

questions.question: For wildlife/sports, which body gives a feeling of extra "reach" with the same 300 mm lens (tighter framing without cropping later)?
questions.reviewHint: Crop factor narrows FOV → subjects look closer.

questions.question: Which makes it easier to go ultra-wide with the same focal length lens?
questions.reviewHint: Crop factor trims the wide end; full frame keeps it wider.

questions.question: About mounting crop-only lenses (e.g., EF-S/DX) on full-frame bodies:
options: Often not mountable or causes heavy vignetting—use full-frame lenses on full-frame bodies
questions.reviewHint: Use FF lenses for FF bodies; crop-only lenses are not designed for FF coverage.

questions.question: Cost & size comparison (same generation/quality level):
options: Crop bodies/lenses are usually larger and pricier
Full-frame bodies/lenses are generally bigger, heavier, and more expensive
questions.reviewHint: Full-frame systems often mean bigger/ heavier gear and higher cost.

questions.question: Does a crop sensor change a lens's actual focal length?
options: Yes, it multiplies the lens's focal length
No—focal length stays the same; the sensor just captures a narrower field of view
questions.reviewHint: Crop factor affects field of view, not actual focal length.

questions.question: Two cameras are both 24 MP (one full frame, one APS-C). Which typically has larger pixels and can show less noise at the same ISO?
questions.reviewHint: Same MP on larger sensor → bigger pixel pitch, often cleaner at high ISO.

topics.label: Sensor size: full frame vs crop
